 Today we're going to talk about empowering security with generative AI.
This is a topic that the more I read about it, the more experiments I run, it starts
to make more sense that it's actually helping us to do our jobs, in my opinion, a little
bit faster.
It's actually enabling a lot of new capabilities that, in my opinion, are going to be super
helpful for a lot of security researchers on the offensive and defensive side of the
house.
My voice sounds a little different, thanks to the ship yesterday and the beer.
Actually, I like this voice right now.
So this is going to be just sharing my journey to understand some of these concepts.
I'm not a mathematician.
I'm not a data scientist.
I'm just a security researcher trying to share some of my notes, some of my experiments,
and hopefully this makes sense and you can also leave this presentation with some new
knowledge about how to use AI in your job.
And once again, I'm an AI cybersecurity enthusiast, so maybe after this talk you can put that
in your LinkedIn, in your Twitter, whatever you want.
And of course, this is just my work.
Most of it is usually outside of work currently, so I'm helping some teams internally.
But this is a lot of the stuff that I've been trying just to do on my own, a couple weekends,
just trying to read, install a few things, and just share it with the community.
That's the goal.
And I'm a security researcher for the Microsoft Security Research Organization.
And this is my lovely, beautiful dog, Stevie.
This is one of the perks of working from home.
I love it.
She still thinks she's a puppy, so she lays on my lap.
She's a great dane, 125 pounds.
That's a lot.

in that specific order.
And if you want to learn more about my open source contributions, you can go to the OTRF
GitHub repository.
Yeah.

So let's just start with the basics.
What's AI, right?
What's artificial intelligence?
Artificial intelligence is just a way to use algorithms that would enable machines to mimic
human behavior.
And at the same time, this human intelligence is actually the ability to be able to process
information and be able to use that information to then make a prediction or perform a task.

AI is not new.

Actually the term AI was coined, artificial intelligence, was actually coined in a conference

Then machine learning is a subset actually of AI, right?

It's a subset of AI, right?

This is the data.

It uses the concept of neural networks and actual deep neural networks.

And most of this learning, it does it on its own, for example.

So let's just start from the basics.
What's a neural network?
OK.
Hopefully, this will make sense.
So a neuron, it's known as the perceptron.
The perceptron has input and output.
Input is the features of data, let's say, attributes of something that you want to use
for the neuron to predict.
The output is the prediction, right?
In order to go from input to output, there are going to be these concepts of weights,
numerical values that will transform the input and then will actually make it to the output.
And there is the concept of activation functions, which acts as our neurons in our heads.
Some neurons are enabled, some neurons are not enabled, activated, not activated.
These activation functions allows us to take the input and put it into a scope of, let's
say, 0 to 1 to provide some type of output.
You can have a neuron.
You can stack the neurons.
You can have multiple layers of neurons.
And those are known as the hidden layers in a neural network.
You have an input.
You have an output layer, as I mentioned before.
If you go from left to right, that's known as forward propagation.
And the reason why I'm talking about this terminology is because when you start reading
papers, when you start reading some of the architectures of transformers, you're going
to start reading about that, like, feed-forward neural networks.
This is what it is.
When you go from left to right, input to output, forward propagation.
The learning occurs in the hidden layers, because now data is being transformed using
weights and then a prediction is part of the output, as in this step.
Now if you know what it is that you want to predict, if you say, hey, this is what I want
you to predict, and you get the prediction, you're going to start calculating what is
called the loss, the mistakes.
And usually when you're training a model, there's going to be a lot of mistakes initially.
It's going to try to understand what set of weights are the most efficient to be able
to predict closer to the actual value.
This loss goes through the process called backpropagation.
And backpropagation simply is trying to understand how does each weight contribute to the overall
loss.
So it goes from the output backwards, it starts calculating, I have these weights, now how
is this affecting my loss, and it goes all the way back.
That's backpropagation.
And the idea is that you can actually take weights and you can set them into this graph
where you can understand where the weight is from the loss.
And if you want to optimize, minimize the loss, that means that the weight needs to
start going down.
And when you start applying these concepts, we use something called as the gradient.
And the gradient would allow you to, by default, optimize a value.
Since we want to minimize loss, we need to do a negative gradient.
That's called gradient descent, for example.
So if you see those terminologies, that's pretty much what it is.
It's allowing you to minimize the loss.
So you can tweak the weights after that, and you will be able to define what set of weights
would allow a neural network to perform the way how you want it to perform.
So this goes like this.
Left to right, goes through a process, predicts something, understands where the weight is
compared to the loss.
It tweaks the weights.
It does it again.
Back propagation.
Goes down.
The weights are moving.
Hopefully you can see that.
And that's the whole process.
That's how you are training a neural network.

What set of weights are the right weights to be able to predict something or be able

So this is what I was talking about, feedforward neural networks.
This is just the basics.
And in this case, the idea here is that data flows from input to output.

So in this case, this is very interesting because when you start thinking about how
do I apply this to text, to language, for example, to sentences, it's very interesting
because with this basic input to output, we don't have a sense of a sequence.
Most of the inputs are just thrown through a neural network and make it learn something.
But if you want to start processing, for example, a sentence, a sequence of text, you
have to do something different.
So the first approach was, why don't we just take one input, send it to the neural network,
make it do something, send the second one, the third one, and the fourth.
So you can start processing input in a sequence, not just everything at once.
The problem with this was that some of the output that is processed at the end might
depend on the input that happened earlier.
So in this case, this is the concept that people started just innovating.
Why don't we just add a relationship between these neural network iterations and we add
the concept of a state.
So if I perform some type of computation in one input, I can save that, pass it to the
next iteration, and do the same thing all over if the input has five words.
So how can you process, for example, five words or one sentence?
That was the concept of what is known as a recurring neural network.
So we're adding recurrence to a basic feedforward neural network.
So this is the foundations, the basics of, for example, sequence modeling, where you
could say many to one.
What does that mean?
Many to one could be, for example, a phishing email.
So there's a lot of text sequence of words, and all you want is to say, is this phishing
or not?
That's your output.
So many to one.
All the way to many to many, which is text translation.
And the concept of recurring neural networks was the basis for that.

And these are very useful concepts, because everything that you're going to be doing from

through some of these initial steps, like tokenization.
What does that mean?
You have a word, pass it through a tokenizer, and then you have tokens.
So in this case, just to keep it simple, one token is one word.
Some tokens actually say it's only four characters per token.
So now the text is going to be split in a specific way.
Here's the concept of word embeddings.
Now that you have your tokens, there is going to be some vocabulary.
Text embeddings would allow you to then take your tokens.
You will be able to see the numerical representations of those tokens.
And at the end, that numerical representation of the text is what you pass to a neural network.
Now this sounds very basic, but the concept of word embeddings is that it's not just a
text to a numerical value and then let's just pass it to a neural network.
There is actually some semantic representation of this text.
The relationship between text is actually captured in this embedding.
So the words that are similar are going to be close to each other, the numerical representations.
And this is super important for language translation in general.
Any type of natural language task, for example.
So if you want to train a language model, you need to understand tokenize.
Not just train it, but also even use it.
Understand how do you pass your text.
Tokenize it.
Word embeddings is one of your first steps.

of the sentence.
And then that's what is used later.
Once the model is actually trained, you can actually start translating text.

one word at a time, it's not going to be efficient.
Two, larger text, the embedding is going to be crazy, the last embedding first, and it's
going to be hard to actually capture this in memory as well.
And then at the same time, it does not truly understand the context of words because it's
not understanding the relationships in the one word that was in the first paragraph,
last word in the last paragraph, it's going to be hard to capture that relationship.
So this is why transformers were introduced in 2017, a way to reduce how we send input

That's something why recurrence was important.
You pass a word, you say, all right, this was first word, second word, third word.
Well, transformers take the concept of let's get the embeddings of each word.
Let's add the position of each word.

That's pretty much what it is.
